history.text: I really enjoyed this movie.... I think Spielberg does an excellent job in his more serious films. And I love Tom Hanks as the lead actor... how did you feel about the film?
I also liked the movie as well, meryl streep is a really good actress
How do you feel about Katherine Graham and her being the first female publisher for a major newspaper?

I think it was a good subject for the film, and I agree with you that Streep captured the role very well. It's always difficult to balance historical accuracy and an entertaining plot, but I think the film did that well. It definitely gave me a lot of information about a subject I wasn't too well-versed in
I agree with your point as well. It was during the early 1970's so it was definitely controversial.

Did you like Bob Odenkirk in the supporting role? I feel like his career has taken off in recent years. 
\

I did like his supporting role but I feel as if the rotten tomato score should have been better than an 88
, do you agree

Yeah, though I do know it's very hard to get a very high score on there. Ideally, it would have been higher. But I know some movies that I felt have been very good received significantly lower scores. I'm curious as to how well it did commercially.
I as well, the critical responses were good with one person stating "the post passes the trickiest test of historical drama" and i definitely agree
I liked the cinematography as well... overall I just thought it was a great film
The scene with Ellsberg going along with the troops was also very striking... I thought it set the tone for the movie, and captured a lot of the controversy and uncertainty surrounding the war
I as well, I like how the movie revealed classified american documents about the Vietnam War
What did you think about the scene with Ellsberg leaking the documents to the New York Times?
I liked it, it showed me how cut throat the world of the press is. How did you feel when he stated that the war was hopeless?
I think it captured what a lot of Americans at the time were feeling, and it was a good way to sort of humanize the characters.
I agree, I also agreed with his decisions to photocopy and release the truth to the press
So the other scene with him trying to track down the leak was very intense... I thought it added a lot of excitement to the film
I agree, when the team of post reporters sorted through all of the piles of paper work searching for headline stories it showed great teamwork
What did you think about Graham's decision to run the story when facing legal issues in doing so?
I agree with Graham's decision because she could potential make history if she was to win in court if legal issues arose.
That's a good point
Again, something that adds a lot of depth to the film
How do you feel about the lawyers for the post advising against publishing the material?

I think it helped hype up the dilemma
 that was occurring as to whether to release the information or not
The last scene with the white house retaliating was a dramatic scene... it was very cool to see other newspapers publishing in solidarity with the Times.
And watching how that ties into Watergate was really interesting
Do you think that the White house retaliating was a bad thing?
I think they were trying to cover their own best interests, but going after the press isn't something I agreed with.
The movie made you root for Graham, and I think the outcome was very pleasing from a viewer's perspective
I agree because as Americans, we have the right to the first amendment. I was definitely rooting for graham as well. I am glad that they won in court 6-3

Would you recommend
 this movie to family/friends?
I would definitely recommend this movie to family and friends, it was exciting
Would you recommend?
I believe I would, it's a very interesting movie and had a lot of excitement as well
Great!
